title: Authors and Citation
text: Doedens C (2026). ewgraph: Equal width representation chance graphs. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://github.com/cfjdoedens/ewgraph.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ewgraph: Equal width representation of chance graphs},   author = {Crist-Jan Doedens},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/cfjdoedens/ewgraph}, }

what: Equal width representation of chance graphs
title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: goal ewgraph represent manipulate chance graphs finite grid data elements. individual elements called segments. grid formed tibble. segment row tibble. package design based information hiding: idea users can know details chance graph represented. possibly use knowledge unforeseen ways.

title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: can install development version ewgraph GitHub :

title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(ewgraph) # Construct an ewgraph of 1000 segments, resulting from a binomial draw of 300 samples, # with ten errors found. g <- ew_from_vec(dbinom(x = 10, size = 300, partition_0_1(1000)))  # Get most probable value for the error fraction, p, and accompanying  # probability density, h. most_prob_ph <- ew_maxh(g) print(most_prob_ph) #>        h        p  #> 38.29659  0.03350  # Get maximum value for the error fraction, p, given # certainty level cert. max_error_rate <- ew_maxcumh_p(g, .95) print(max_error_rate) #> [1] 0.05571198

title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: equal width probability graph, ewgraph, finite numeric representation function c domain P codomain H. c:P→Hc: P \rightarrow HPP real numbers [0,1][0, 1]. HH real numbers [0,inf][0,inf]. cc interpreted context function maps error fraction pp chance density error fraction. h=c(p)h = c(p) cc absolutely continuous probability distribution. cc probability density function. function, cc, represented ewgraph finite set SS pairs (pi,hi)(p_i, h_i), ii 1:S1:S. SS positive integer. pip_i elements P, [0, 1]. hih_i elements H, [0, inf]. hi=c(pi)h_i = c(p_i) Let U=1/(2*S)U = 1 / (2 * S) define ith segment PP [/S−1/S,/S][/ S - 1 / S, / S]. segments equal width, 1/S=2*U1 / S = 2 * U. SS segments. middle ith segment pi=/(S−U)p_i = /(S - U) segments : [0,1/S],[1/S,2/S],...,[(S−1)/S,1][0, 1/S], [1/S, 2/S], ..., [(S - 1)/S, 1]

title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: important aspect segment surface. probability density function, probability outcome lies certain segment P proportional surface segment. approximate surface probability function surfaces segments corresponding equal width probability graph. sum surfaces segments definition 1. first approximation can equal surface segment hi*(1/S)h_i * (1/S). See drawing segment surfacei=length..segment*height..segmentsurface_i = length..segment * height..segment=(pi+U−(pi−U)))*hi          = (p_i + U - (p_i - U))) * h_i=2U*hi= 2U * h_i=(1/S)*hi= (1/S) * h_i probability graph rather flat nice approximation. However steep parts graph, approximation less good fit. improve approximate surface segment computing also height begin end points segment. computing hpi−U≡hleftih_{p_{-U}} \equiv hleft_i, hpi+U≡hrightih_{p_{+U}} \equiv hright_i. can compute surface segment ii sum left right parts. surfacei=surface.lefti+surface.rightisurface_i = surface.left_i + surface.right_isurface.lefti=length..left.halve..segmenti*(hlefti+hi)/2surface.left_i  = length..left.halve..segment_i *                    (hleft_i + h_i) / 2=U*(hlefti+hi)/2= U*(hleft_i + h_i) / 2surface.righti=length..right.halve..segmenti*(hi+hrighti)/2surface.right_i = length..right.halve..segment_i *                   (h_i + hright_i) / 2=U*(hi+hrighti)/2= U*(h_i + hright_i) / 2surfacei=U*(hlefti+hi)/2+U*(hi+hrighti)/2surface_i = U*(hleft_i + h_i) / 2 + U*(h_i + hright_i) / 2=(hlefti+hrighti+2*hi)*U/2= (hleft_i + hright_i + 2 * h_i) * U / 2 compute hleftihleft_i hrightihright_i interpolation. hleftihleft_i proceed: Let him1=c(pim1)h_{im1} = c(p_{im1}) im1im1 stands −1i - 1. interpolate: hlefti=(hi+him1)/2hleft_i  = (h_i + h_{im1}) / 2 vein get hrighti=(hi+hip1)/2hright_i = (h_i + h_{ip1}) / 2 leaves us problem interpolate leftmost hleftihleft_i, hleft1hleft_1, rightmost hrightihright_i, hrightShright_S. , can interpolate h_i segment 0 segment S+1S+1, segments exist. cases instead interpolating extrapolate. hleft1hleft_1: line coordinates (U,h1)(U, h_1) (3*U,h2)(3 * U, h_2) algebraic form y=ax+= ax+b. h1=*U+bh_1 = * U + bh2=*3*U+bh_2 = * 3 * U + b get =(h2−h1)/(2*U)= (h_2 - h_1) / (2 * U)b=(3*h1−h2)/2b = (3 * h_1 - h_2) / 2 hleft1hleft_1 get hleft1=*0+bhleft_1 = * 0 + b=b= b=(3*h1−h2)/2= (3 * h_1 - h_2) / 2 However, note hleft1hleft_1 become less 0. forbid, imply negative probability density. , taking account get: hleft1=max(0,(3*h1−h2)/2)hleft_1 = max(0, (3 * h_1 - h_2) / 2) hrightShright_S: line coordinates (1−3*U,hSm1)(1 - 3 * U, h_{Sm1}) (1−U,hS)(1 - U, h_S) algebraic form y=ax+= ax+b hSm1=*(1−3*U)+bh_{Sm1} = * (1 - 3 * U) + bhS=*(1−U)+bh_S   = * (1 - U) + b get =(hS−hSm1)/(2*U)= (h_S - h_{Sm1}) / (2 * U)b=hS+(hSm1−hS)*(1−U)/(2*U)b = h_S + (h_{Sm1} - h_S) * (1 - U) / (2 * U) hrightShright_S get hrightS=*1+bhright_S = * 1 + b=+b= + b=(hS−hSm1)/(2*U)+hS+(hSm1−hS)*(1−U)/(2*U)= (h_S - h_{Sm1}) / (2 * U) + h_S + (h_{Sm1} - h_S) * (1 - U) / (2 * U)=(3*hS−hSm1)/2= (3 * h_S - h_{Sm1}) / 2 outcome symmetric hleft1=(3*h1−h2)/2hleft_1 = (3 * h_1 - h_2)/ 2 hleft1hleft_1 forbid negative values hrightShright_S. , taking account get: hrightS=max(0,(3*hS−hSm1)/2)hright_S = max(0, (3 * h_S - h_{Sm1}) / 2)

what: Representation of a segment from an ewgraph as a geometric figure
title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: See figure . segment ewgraph ABDEF can considered consist two rectangular trapeziums, ABCF EDCF, representing respectively left right halve segment. corners ABC CDE rectangular. two trapeziums shared parallel line, CF, length hi. three (one left trapezium, AB, one shared, CF, one right trapezium, DE) parallel lines perpendicular p-axis, BD. lines trapezium BC DC, lie p-axis length U. Line AB length hleftihleft_i. Line ED length hrightihright_i.

what: Comparison with standard numerical approximation of an integral
title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: cite Wikipedia: calculus, definite integral arbitrary function f(x) can numerically approximated discrete sum partitioning interval integration small uniform intervals approximating function’s value interval average values endpoints. see correspondence small uniform intervals used calculating definite integral segments ewgraph. contrast cited method ewgraph essence based middle value segment. reason choice typically probability graph realm dealing , might infinite height p=0p = 0 p=1p = 1. steering clear values, avoid problem. Furthermore think using one middle value segment representative elegant symmetric using values end points representative. also matter taste.

what: Representation of ewgraph as R tibble
title: Equal width representation of chance graphs
text: programming language R represent ewgraph tibble S rows. ith segment ewgraph following variables: p[[]] = /S - U, means p[[]] mid point ith segment h[[]] = c(p[[]]) h[[]] chance p[[]] h_left[[]] linear interpolation h[[]] h[[-1]] (linear extrapolation h[[1]] h[[2]] h_left[[1]]) h_right[[]] linear interpolation h[[]] h[[+1]] (linear extrapolation h[[S]] h[[S-1]] h_right(S)) surface[[]] surface ith segment. cumsurface[[]] cumulative surface[[]], going 1

title: Create vector of densities over [0, 1] — density_over_0_1
text: values equal 0 counted first bucket.

title: Create vector of densities over [0, 1] — density_over_0_1
code: y <- seq(0, 1, length.out=33)     x <- density_over_0_1(values_from_0_1 = y, S = 12)

what: highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
title: highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
text: highest part graph given cumulative chance density

title: highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
text: g ewgraph. high_density_area 1 return g . smaller 1, highest part ewgraph g shown cumulative chance density equal high_density_interval idea cuts away uninteresting low value left /right part graph, leaves rest.

title: highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
text: vector form c(left = i_left, right = i_right). i_left i_right respectively leftmost rightmost ew segment HDI.

title: highest part of the graph with a given cumulative chance density — ew_high_density_interval
code: S <- 1000   g <- ew_from_vec(dbinom(30, 300, partition_0_1(S)))   lr  <- ew_high_density_interval(g)   print(lr) #>  left right  #>    54   166

what: maximum error rate for given certainty — ew_maxcumh_p

title: maximum error rate for given certainty — ew_maxcumh_p
maximum error rate for given certainty — ew_maxcumh_p
text: g ewgraph. cert certainty. Lies 0 1.

title: maximum error rate for given certainty — ew_maxcumh_p
text: maximum error rate g, given certainty cert.

title: maximum error rate for given certainty — ew_maxcumh_p
code: S <- 1000   g <- ew_from_vec(dbinom(30, 300, partition_0_1(S)))   max_cumh_p <- ew_maxcumh_p(g)   print(max_cumh_p) #> [1] 0.1327614

code: S <- 1000   g <- ew_from_vec(dbinom(30, 300, partition_0_1(S)))   hp_max <- ew_maxh(g)   print(hp_max) #>        h        p  #> 23.03533  0.10050

what: ewgraph: Equal width representation of chance graphs — ewgraph-package

title: ewgraph: Equal width representation of chance graphs — ewgraph-package
text: Maintainer: Crist-Jan Doedens cfjdoedens@chance-matters.nl

what: Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
title: Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
text: Gather pairs input output monotone rising function function monotone rising. function useful debugging purposes. Show pairs monotone rising inputs, non rising outputs.

title: Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
text: f function test. function takes numeric vector returns numeric vector. in_vals Vector numeric input values f. strictly boolean. TRUE, checks strictly increasing (f(x2) > f(x1)). FALSE (default), checks non-decreasing (f(x2) >= f(x1)).

title: Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
text: data frame columns input1, output1, input2, output2 containing offending pairs input outputs.

title: Find input and output pairs of a function that are not monotone rising. — find_non_monotone_pairs
code: # Example function that is not monotone rising example_function <- function(x) {   ifelse(x < 0.5, x, 1 - x) }  # Find non-monotone pairs in the example function. x <- find_non_monotone_pairs(example_function, seq(   from = 0,   to = 1,   length.out = 100), strictly = FALSE)

what: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
title: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
text: Checks function monotone rising specified interval.

title: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
code: is_monotone_rising(f, range = c(0, 1), n_points = 1000, strictly = FALSE)

title: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
text: f function test. function takes numeric vector returns numeric vector. range numeric vector length 2, defining start end interval check (e.g., c(0, 100)). n_points number points sample within range. points, thorough check. strictly boolean. TRUE, checks strictly increasing (f(x2) > f(x1)). FALSE (default), checks non-decreasing (f(x2) >= f(x1)).

title: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
text: TRUE function monotone rising sampled points, FALSE otherwise.

title: Checks if a function is monotone rising over a specified interval. — is_monotone_rising
code: f_linear_large <- function(x) 2 * x + 5   should_be_true <- is_monotone_rising(f_linear_large,                                        range = c(-1e6, 1e6),                                        n_points = 1000)

title: One argument constant function that returns 1 — unity
code: # Returns 1.   unity(-0.034) #> [1] 1    # Returns 1.   unity(rnorm(1, mean = 10^10, sd = 10^20)) #> [1] 1    # Returns 1.   unity(NaN) #> [1] 1    # Returns 1.   unity(Inf) #> [1] 1    # Returns c(1, 1).   unity(c(3, 7)) #> [1] 1 1    # An error is generated for non-numeric input.   tryCatch({     unity("a")   }, error = function(e) {     cat('unity("a") procuded the following error message:', conditionMessage(e), "\n")     NA   }) #> unity("a") procuded the following error message: is.numeric(x) is not TRUE  #> [1] NA
